history.content: The existence of an efficient decryption algorithm is enough to prove that the proposed cryptosystem is not secure. Such a decryption algorithm would allow an eavesdropper to decode the contents of an encrypted message in a reasonable (not exponential) amount of time.

In the RSA cryptosystem, the person who wants to receive an encrypted message (Bob) publishes the public key $$(N, e)$$ for the entire world to see. Then when someone (Alice) wants to send Bob a message, they can encrypt their message $$m$$ using the encryption formula $$y = m^e \mod N$$. The encrypted message $$y$$ can only be decoded using the decryption formula $$y^d = (m^e)^d = m^{1 + k\phi(N)} \equiv m \mod N$$. The decryption key $$d$$ is computed as $$d = e^{-1} \mod \phi(N) = e^{-1} \mod ((p-1)(q-1))$$.

Bob can compute the decryption key quickly because he knows that that $$N = pq$$ and therefore $$\phi(N) = (p-1)(q-1)$$. No one else can compute $$d$$ without first factoring $$N$$ into $$p*q$$, which would take an exponential amount of time. The inherent difficulty of factoring $$N$$ is what makes RSA secure.

The only difference with this new cryptosystem is that $$N = p$$ (rather than $$N = pq$$). So now the decryption key is not so difficult for an eavesdropper to compute. For this problem, you should just describe how an eavesdropper could use the public information $$(N=p, e)$$ to decrypt $$y$$ back into the original message $$m$$.

The existence of an efficient decryption algorithm is enough to prove that the proposed cryptosystem is not secure. Such a decryption algorithm would allow an eavesdropper to decode the contents of an encrypted message in a reasonable (not exponential) amount of time.

For this particular problem, you can prove that the proposed cryptosystem is insecure by describing an an algorithm that given $$p$$, $$e$$, and $$m^e \mod p$$ as inputs, computes the original message $$m\mod p$$ in an efficient amount of time.

So I think I know what I want to say for the last part of the homework, but I don't know about putting it in the right format or sequence of steps to be a sound proof.  Is there a general pattern you'd like our proofs to follow? I suppose it wouldn't be enough to give an example to the contrary of what we're trying to prove.
history.subject: RSA Proof
